title: Dubai residents snub home insurance cover despite fire risk
text:
Dubai residents snub home insurance cover despite fire risk Article By Staff writer Friday, 28 August 2015 1:10 AM 
More than 60 percent of Dubai residents do not have home insurance, according to a new poll conducted by MoveSouq.com, a Dubai-based online home services marketplace. 
The survey, carried out in conjunction with insurer RSA, showed that only a quarter of tenants have home insurance while 66 percent of home owners have policies. 
The survey, based on the responses of more than 200 people, also showed that 67 percent of apartment units and 50 percent of villas in Dubai are uninsured. 
MoveSouq.com CEO Bana Shomali said: "Given the widely reported incidents of apartment building fires in major residential areas of Dubai, it is quite surprising that so many homes remain uninsured even when basic content insurance is widely available and affordable." 
On the other hand, health and car insurance are widely adopted in Dubai. Over 90 percent of employed Dubai residents reported they have medical insurance, while all respondents that drive confirmed they have motor insurance - no surprise as they are mandated by the government. 
The survey also revealed that some of the other insurance policies with low penetration levels among employed Dubai residents were travel insurance (36 percent), personal accident insurance (40 percent) and life insurance (45 percent). 
Commenting on these results, David Harris, RSA's sales & marketing director, said: "While it is not surprising to see that the uptake of home content insurance remains low in Dubai, it is alarming that it is used the least compared to other types of insurance with only 3 out of 10 saying they have applied for it. 
"These penetration levels are far lower than more mature markets in the West and can be attributed to the prevailing perception among a majority of residents that home and content insurance is not necessary or that it is not worth the expense. 
"Furthermore, we have seen that people are often only likely to consider this type of insurance once the damage has already been done."
